edu.duke

Class RangeResource

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.duke.RangeResource

  • public class RangeResource
extends java.lang.Object
    The RangeResource class represents a range of integer (or whole) numbers and allows access to these numbers using the method sequence. The integers can then be iterated over using a for loop

    Example usage: 

     // this prints the square number sequence for the first 9 numbers:
 //   1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81 
 RangeResource rr = new RangeResource(1, 10);
 for (int value : rr.sequence()) {
     System.out.println(value * value);
 }

    Another example usage: 

     // this prints the odd numbers in decreasing order within the given range:
 //   37, 35, 33, 31, 29, 27, 25, 23
 RangeResource rr = new RangeResource(37, 21, -2);
 for (int value : rr.sequence()) {
     System.out.println(value);
 }

    This software is licensed with an Apache 2 license, see http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 for details.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      RangeResource(int end)
      Create a RangeResource object, starting at 0 and going up to but not including end, [0 - end), that increments by 1.
      RangeResource(int start, int end)
      Create a RangeResource object, starting at start and going up to but not including end, [start - end), that increments by 1.
      RangeResource(int start, int end, int increment)
      Create a RangeResource object, starting at start and going up to but not including end, [start - end), that increments by the amount passed as a parameter.
      RangeResource(RangeResource other)
      Create an RangeResource object that is a copy of another range.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer> sequence()
      Allow access to the numbers in this range one at a time.
      java.lang.String toString()
      Return string representation of this range, with each value in the sequence separated by a comma.

    • Constructor Detail

      • RangeResource

        public RangeResource(int end)
        Create a RangeResource object, starting at 0 and going up to but not including end, [0 - end), that increments by 1.
        Parameters:
        end - when to stop the range, not included as one of the values

      • RangeResource

        public RangeResource(int start,
                     int end)
        Create a RangeResource object, starting at start and going up to but not including end, [start - end), that increments by 1.
        Parameters:
        start - the first value in the range, included as one of the values
        end - when to stop the range, not included as one of the values

      • RangeResource

        public RangeResource(int start,
                     int end,
                     int increment)
        Create a RangeResource object, starting at start and going up to but not including end, [start - end), that increments by the amount passed as a parameter.
        Parameters:
        start - the first value in the range, included as one of the values
        end - when to stop the range, not included as one of the values
        increment - how much to add to get the next value in the range's sequence
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if increment is negative when the end is greater than the start
        ResourceException - if increment is positive when the end is less than the start
        ResourceException - if increment is 0

      • RangeResource

        public RangeResource(RangeResource other)
        Create an RangeResource object that is a copy of another range.
        Parameters:
        other - the original range being copied

    • Method Detail

      • sequence

        public java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer> sequence()
        Allow access to the numbers in this range one at a time.
        Returns:
        an Iterable that will allow access to each number in this range

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Return string representation of this range, with each value in the sequence separated by a comma.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a String containing all the values in the range
